Mg orthovanadate crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Cmca with a = 6.053(3), b = 11.442(6), c = 8.330(3) Ã , and Z = 4. The structure was refined by full matrix least square methods to a final R value of 0.047 by using 1697 reflections measured by a quarter circle General Electric automatic diffractometer. The structure was assumed to be isomorphous with that of Ni3(VO4)2, reported by Durif and Bertaut, and the refinement started by using the same fractional at. coordinates. The structure consists of nearly cubic closest packing of O atom layers roughly normal to the [01 ] direction with the Mg ions in 2 types of octahedral sites and the V ion in a tetrahedral site. The VO4 group has a crystallog. mirror plane. The cations lying on sites of Cm symmetry show an av. Mg-O bond length of 2.092 Ã , compared to 2.098 Ã for cations lying at sites of C2h symmetry. The anion deviates significantly and substantially from regularity with the 3 O atoms shared with only 2 cations showing V-O bond lengths within 0.015 Ã of their mean, 1.70 Ã , whereas the remaing O atom, which is shared with three Mg ions, lies 1.809 Ã from the V ion. The structure has characteristics similar to those of spinel.

A series of vanadium compds. was studied by K-edge X-ray absorption (XAS) and KÎ² X-ray emission spectroscopies (XES). Qual. trends within the datasets, as well as comparisons between the XAS and XES data, illustrate the information content of both methods. The complementary nature of the chem. insight highlights the success of this dual-technique approach in characterizing both the structural and electronic properties of vanadium sites. In particular, and in contrast to XAS or extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS), we demonstrate that valence-to-core XES is capable of differentiating between ligating atoms with the same identity but different bonding character. Finally, d. functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent DFT calcns. enable a more detailed, quant. interpretation of the data. We also establish correction factors for the computational protocols through calibration to expt. These hard X-ray methods can probe vanadium ions in any oxidn. or spin state, and can readily be applied to sample environments ranging from solid-phase catalysts to biol. samples in frozen soln. Thus, the combined XAS and XES approach, coupled with DFT calcns., provides a robust tool for the study of vanadium atoms in bioinorg. chem.

The authors present and discuss the O 1 s and V 2p x-ray absorption spectra (XAS) of several V oxides with different formal valences and chem. environments. The O 1s XAS spectra reflect the unoccupied electronic states in the conduction band and provide very useful information on crystal-field splitting, band width and hybridization strength. The O 1s XAS spectrum of VO2 in the metallic phase is properly reproduced by an O p partial d. of unoccupied states calcd. with the localized-spherical-wave method. The O 1s XAS spectra of VO2 taken at 300 K (semiconducting phase) and 390 K (metallic phase) show clearly the splitting of the V 3d bands across the semiconductor-metal transition (Tc â 340K). The V 2p XAS spectra present significant multiplet effects and chem. shifts which provide very helpful information on the character and symmetry of the ground state. The V 2p XAS spectrum of V2O3 is precisely simulated by an at.-multiplet calcn. projected on the appropriate crystal-field. The V 2p XAS spectra of the (Li,Zn) V2O4 series present clear chem. shifts and considerable changes in the shape of the multiplets. These effects denote a change in the character of the ground state and show that the holes induced by Li substitution in ZnV2O4 contain mainly V 3d character.

The development of rechargeable Mg/S batteries is driven by the design of reliable electrolytes. To date, they seem not suitable for industrial transfer as they are either corrosive or necessitate a complex formulation. The innovative strategy reported here, which replaces magnesium by Mg alloys at the neg. electrode, enables employing facile electrolyte formulations as well as proposes an easier electrode-shaping process. As a proof-of-concept, Mg3Bi2/S cells were evaluated with simple Mg(TFSI)2/DME electrolyte. Electrochem. mechanisms including Mg3Bi2 dealloying and sulfur magnesiation were probed by X-ray diffraction and X-ray photoelectron spectrocsopy, resp. In addn., very promising cycling performance at elevated c.d. is obtained. These preliminary findings pave the way for addnl. improvements toward further practical applications.

Tertiary Mg/MgCl2/AlCl3 Inorganic Mg2+ Electrolytes with Unprecedented Electrochemical Performance for Reversible Mg Deposition
Luo, Jian; He, Shuijian; Liu, T. Leo

(

)
Because of the high reactivity and sensitivity of Mg2+ electrolytes in org. solvents, developing facile methods of prepg. high-performance Mg2+ electrolytes is still challenging and thus impedes the development of Mg batteries. A convenient method involving tertiary reactants, Mg powder, MgCl2, and AlCl3, is reported to prep. all-inorg. Mg2+ electrolytes (termed MMAC electrolytes) in ethereal solvents. These MMAC electrolytes exhibited unprecedented performance for reversible Mg deposition, Coulombic efficiencies at 90-100%, overpotential of 125-215 mV, and anodic stability up to 3.5-3.8 V (vs. Mg). A comprehensive fundamental study of the MMAC electrolytes showed that the electron transfer and mass transport kinetics during Mg deposition and stripping were affected by solvent, working electrode, and the compn. of the electrolytes. In brief, these tertiary MMAC electrolytes represent the most facile and reliable inorg. Mg electrolytes known to date.
